snippet.title: Cricket pay deal struck
snippet.content:
Australia's cricketers will continue to be the highest paid locally-based athletes after the ended with a new deal that will pay them up to $500 million in the next five years The average pay of Cricket Australia-contracted male players, including Big Bash League contracts, will rise from $1.16 million this year to $1.45 million by 2022 and top-ranked players will earn at least $2 million annually. Female players will have their average pay increased by 166 per cent over five years from $79,000 previously to $179,000 this season to $210,000 by 2022. Players will also be back-paid to June 30 and share in $58 million owed to them under the terms of the recently expired memorandum of understanding with Cricket Australia.
The deal , which included players going unpaid from July 1 and Cricket Australia unsuccessfully attempting to end 20 years of gross revenue sharing with the players.
Terms for a new five-year memorandum of understanding were signed after a final round of negotiations between Cricket Australia chief executive James Sutherland and Australian Cricketers' Association boss Alistair Nicholson in Melbourne on Thursday morning before a formal announcement in the afternoon. Players will receive about 30 per cent of revenue from agreed sources, including forecast revenue streams in a modified revenue-sharing model. Both Cricket Australia and the players will contribute $25 million each to a grassroots investment fund over five years, which will fund improvements to junior facilities and training programs. A joint committee will oversee the spending of the funds.
